weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Enable OS patch management
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly update all GCP Compute Engine instances with the latest patches and security updates using OS patch management tools. This helps protect your infrastructure from known vulnerabilities and ensures your instances are running secure versions of their operating systems. Configure automated patch management where possible, and schedule regular reviews to ensure all instances remain compliant with security standards.

Reference:

  • OS patch management for Compute Engine

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all data transmitted between Compute Engine instances and services is encrypted to protect sensitive information from being intercepted or tampered with during transit. Utilize TLS or other encryption protocols to secure communication channels between instances and services, ensuring compliance with security and privacy standards.

Reference:

This helps reduce the attack surface and prevents unauthorized access to instances.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unpatched or outdated operating systems
threat.desc:
General threat description
Operating systems that are not regularly updated with security patches are vulnerable to exploitation. These vulnerabilities can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access, escalate privileges, or disrupt services running on GCP Compute Engine instances.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, or automated tools that scan for known vulnerabilities in outdated or unpatched systems. These attackers may leverage publicly available exploits or zero-day vulnerabilities to compromise vulnerable systems.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data or services
  • Compromised system integrity
  • Service disruption or outages due to malicious exploitation
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses a known exploit to target a vulnerability in an outdated operating system running on a Compute Engine instance, gaining unauthorized access to the instance and extracting sensitive data.
  2. A malicious actor deploys ransomware on an unpatched Compute Engine instance, exploiting an old vulnerability to lock down services, demanding payment to restore functionality.
  3. An automated bot scans the network for outdated operating systems and uses a vulnerability in an unpatched service to gain root access to the instance.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description
When data is transmitted over the network without encryption, it becomes vulnerable to interception and compromise by attackers. Unencrypted data transmission increases the risk of unauthorized access to sensitive information, especially when communicating between GCP Compute Engine instances, services, and external systems.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can intercept unencrypted traffic using methods such as man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, or compromising insecure communication channels.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive information such as credentials, personal data, or proprietary information
  • Data breaches or unauthorized access to confidential communications
  • Compliance violations for industries requiring encrypted transmission (e.g., healthcare, finance)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses a packet-sniffing tool to capture unencrypted traffic between two GCP Compute Engine instances, extracting sensitive credentials.
  2. A MitM attacker intercepts unencrypted API requests between a Compute Engine instance and a cloud service, altering or stealing the data in transit.
  3. During a data transfer between a client and a Compute Engine instance, an attacker captures unencrypted personal data, leading to a data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1052 - Exfiltration Over Physical Medium

threat.name: Inadequate network isolation
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failure to properly isolate GCP Compute Engine instances from other network resources increases the risk of unauthorized lateral movement within the environment. Insufficient network segmentation allows attackers or malicious users to move between systems, potentially compromising sensitive data or services.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external attackers, malware, and malicious insiders can exploit the lack of network isolation to gain access to other systems or sensitive data, increasing the scope of an attack.

Impacts

  • Lateral movement across systems leading to broader compromise
  • Increased risk of data theft or manipulation
  • Unauthorized access to internal services
  • Compromise of mission-critical workloads

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker compromises one Compute Engine instance and, due to inadequate network isolation, is able to move laterally to other instances hosting sensitive workloads.
  2. Malware infects one virtual machine and spreads to other systems in the same network due to the lack of proper segmentation, compromising the entire environment.
  3. A misconfigured network allows internal users to access sensitive systems they are not authorized to interact with, leading to accidental or intentional data exposure.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Exposure to external threats due to open firewall rules
threat.desc:
General threat description
Overly permissive firewall rules can expose GCP Compute Engine instances to external attacks, increasing the risk of unauthorized access and exploitation of vulnerabilities. Improperly configured firewall rules may allow unwanted traffic from untrusted sources.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers, automated bots, and malicious insiders can exploit open or misconfigured firewall rules to gain access to sensitive systems or exploit known vulnerabilities in exposed services.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to systems and data
  • Increased attack surface for external threats
  • Potential for service disruption due to denial-of-service (DoS) attacks
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in exposed services

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A hacker scans public IP addresses for open ports and finds a Compute Engine instance with permissive firewall rules, allowing them to access and compromise the system.
  2. A misconfigured firewall rule allows external access to an administrative port (e.g., SSH), and an attacker brute-forces the login credentials to gain unauthorized control of the instance.
  3. Open firewall rules permit a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack that overwhelms the instance, causing it to crash or become unresponsive.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate authentication controls
threat.desc:
General threat description
Weak or improperly configured authentication controls can allow unauthorized users to access GCP Compute Engine instances and associated services. Insufficient authentication mechanisms increase the risk of account compromise, unauthorized resource access, and potential data breaches.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit weak passwords, stolen credentials, or poorly configured authentication policies to gain access to GCP Compute Engine instances. Brute force attacks, phishing, and social engineering are common vectors used to bypass inadequate authentication controls.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data or systems
  • Service disruptions or hijacking of Compute Engine resources
  • Compromised accounts and escalation of privileges

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A user account with weak or reused credentials is compromised by an attacker, granting them access to a GCP Compute Engine instance.
  2. An attacker uses a phishing campaign to obtain login credentials from employees, allowing them to bypass weak authentication controls.
  3. Poorly configured authentication settings allow an unauthorized user to access internal services running on Compute Engine without proper verification.

countermeasure.name: Apply least privilege for DNS record management
countermeasure.desc:
Use Google Cloud IAM roles and permissions to implement the principle of least privilege for DNS record management. Ensure that only authorized users with specific roles can modify DNS records. Assign permissions carefully, restricting access to users or services that need it to minimize the risk of unauthorized changes. Regularly review and audit permissions to ensure compliance with security best practices and remove excessive or outdated access rights.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP IAM Best Practices

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: Configure DNS queries to use HTTPS for encrypted transmission
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all DNS queries are sent over HTTPS (DNS over HTTPS, or DoH) to protect data in transit from being intercepted or tampered with by malicious actors. By encrypting DNS traffic, you safeguard DNS queries and responses from potential man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks and ensure that sensitive information is not exposed on the network. Regularly verify that all DNS traffic is encrypted using DoH to maintain a secure DNS environment.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP DNS Security Documentation

customField.value: ATT&CK ICS - M0808 - Encrypt Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enable DNSSEC to authenticate DNS responses
countermeasure.desc:
Enable DNSSEC (Domain Name System Security Extensions) for your Cloud DNS managed zones to protect against DNS spoofing attacks. DNSSEC uses digital signatures to authenticate DNS responses, ensuring that clients only receive valid and untampered responses from authoritative DNS servers. Implement DNSSEC to prevent attackers from injecting fraudulent DNS data and redirecting traffic to malicious websites. Regularly monitor DNSSEC configurations to maintain a secure DNS environment.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP DNSSEC Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enable logging for all DNS changes
countermeasure.desc:
Enable logging for all changes to DNS records in GCP to ensure a comprehensive audit trail of DNS modifications. Use Cloud Logging to track and monitor any changes made to DNS settings, and regularly review the logs to identify suspicious or unauthorized activity. Additionally, set up alerts to notify administrators of any unauthorized modifications or anomalies in real-time, enabling a prompt response to potential security threats.

For more details, refer to:

  • GCP Logging Best Practices

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging for DNS changes
threat.desc:
General threat description
The lack of logging for DNS changes can result in unauthorized modifications going unnoticed. Without proper logging and monitoring, malicious actors or insider threats could alter DNS records, redirecting traffic or compromising services. Failure to detect such changes can lead to prolonged exposure to attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers with stolen credentials, or users with excessive privileges.
  • Attack Vectors: Unauthorized or unnoticed DNS record changes due to lack of logging or monitoring.

Impacts

  • DNS hijacking, redirecting traffic to malicious sites.
  • Service disruptions or unavailability of services due to incorrect DNS configurations.
  • Prolonged compromise due to delayed detection of malicious changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A malicious insider makes unauthorized changes to DNS records, redirecting traffic to a malicious site without being detected because DNS change logs are not monitored.
  2. An attacker with stolen credentials modifies DNS records to launch a phishing campaign, and the changes go unnoticed for days due to the lack of DNS logging and alerts.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: DNS cache poisoning
threat.desc:
General threat description
DNS cache poisoning occurs when an attacker manipulates the cache of a DNS resolver, injecting fraudulent IP addresses for legitimate domain names. This redirects users to malicious websites without their knowledge, leading to data theft, malware distribution, or phishing attacks. Without DNSSEC (Domain Name System Security Extensions), DNS responses are vulnerable to tampering, making cache poisoning a critical risk.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised DNS resolvers, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weaknesses in DNS query/response processes to inject false information into DNS caches.

Impacts

  • Redirection of users to malicious websites, resulting in phishing, data theft, or malware infection.
  • Loss of customer trust and potential brand damage.
  • Compromise of critical infrastructure if services are redirected to attacker-controlled locations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker injects a fake IP address into the DNS cache of a resolver, causing users trying to visit a legitimate banking website to be redirected to a phishing site.
  2. A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a DNS server, poisoning its cache and redirecting traffic meant for a popular online service to a server under their control, where they steal user credentials.

threat.name: Man-in-the-middle attacks on DNS queries
threat.desc:
General threat description
A man-in-the-middle (MitM) attack on DNS queries occurs when an attacker intercepts or alters DNS requests and responses between the client and DNS server. By doing so, the attacker can redirect users to malicious websites, steal sensitive information, or disrupt services. DNS queries that are not encrypted or authenticated are particularly vulnerable to such attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious network intermediaries, or compromised routers.
  • Attack Vectors: Intercepting unencrypted DNS traffic, modifying DNS responses in transit, or spoofing DNS servers to redirect traffic.

Impacts

  • Redirection of users to fraudulent or malicious websites.
  • Data theft, including login credentials or sensitive user information.
  • Service disruption or compromise, resulting in downtime or reputational damage.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker performs a MitM attack by intercepting DNS queries over an unsecured network and responds with malicious IP addresses, redirecting users trying to access a legitimate service to a fake site.
  2. A MitM attack targets public Wi-Fi users, intercepting DNS queries and altering responses to redirect users to a malicious website where their login credentials are stolen.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized modification of DNS records
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized modification of DNS records occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user gains access to modify DNS settings, redirecting traffic to malicious servers or disrupting services. DNS records control how domain names are resolved into IP addresses, and tampering with these records can lead to DNS hijacking, service outages, or data breaches.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised accounts, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak access controls, using stolen credentials, or leveraging misconfigured permissions to modify DNS records.

Impacts

  • DNS hijacking, redirecting traffic to malicious websites.
  • Service disruptions, causing unavailability of critical applications or services.
  • Data theft or phishing attacks, leading to financial loss and reputational damage.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to the DNS management console using stolen credentials and modifies DNS records to redirect website visitors to a malicious server for phishing.
  2. A malicious insider with excessive privileges changes DNS settings, causing a company's email traffic to be routed to an attacker-controlled server, leading to data interception.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-223
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-223: Omission of Security-relevant Information The product does not record or display information that would be important for identifying the source or nature of an attack, or determining if an action is safe.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Block all inbound port traffic from 0.0.0.0/0
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Load Balancing setup, it is critical to implement network security rules that block all inbound traffic from untrusted sources. This is essential in minimizing exposure to potential attacks. Follow these steps to configure your network security rules effectively:

  1. Identify the untrusted sources: Determine which IP ranges are considered untrusted (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0). The default 0.0.0.0/0 represents all IPv4 addresses, and you should explicitly specify trusted sources to ensure only these can access your load balancer.

  2. Access the Google Cloud Console: Navigate to the Firewall rules page in your GCP console.

  3. Create or update firewall rules:

    • Select or create a rule to enforce that inbound traffic from the untrusted source range(s) is disallowed. You can edit existing rules or add new firewall rules as necessary.
    • Ensure your firewall rules are applied to the VMs behind your load balancer by specifying the appropriate network tags or service accounts.

  4. Configure your load balancer:

    • Ensure that the backend service of your load balancer is configured to only accept traffic that passes through the firewall rules. This can be done by associating the backend with secured networks and limiting access only to approved sources.
    • For HTTP(S) load balancing, enable the use of HTTPS traffic management features to further enhance security by requiring secure connections.

  5. Test the configuration: Regularly monitor and test your network security rules to ensure that your configuration effectively blocks inappropriate access and only allows access from trusted sources.

For more detailed information on setting up and maintaining secure load balancing configurations, refer to the GCP Load Balancing Best Practices. This document provides extensive guidance on secure configurations and management of Google Cloud Load Balancing.

countermeasure.name: Configure load balancing with zonal NEGs
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure high availability and improved performance in your application deployments on Google Cloud Platform (GCP), it is recommended to use zonal Network Endpoint Groups (NEGs) for distributing traffic efficiently across different zones. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Understand Zonal NEGs: Zonal NEGs represent groups of service endpoints in specific zones. Utilizing them allows your load balancer to send traffic to instances in the healthiest zones, thereby enhancing reliability and availability.
  2. Create Zonal NEGs: Configure zonal NEGs for your VM instances or services within the specified zones. This ensures that traffic is efficiently directed to appropriate active endpoints in each zone.
  3. Integrate with Load Balancer: After configuring zonal NEGs, integrate them with your HTTP(S) Load Balancer. This ensures that requests are routed based on proximity and health, leveraging Google's global network effectively. The HTTP(S) Load Balancer setup guide provides step-by-step instructions for this configuration.
  4. Monitor and Adjust: Once integrated, continuously monitor the traffic distribution and instances' health status across zones. Use GCP's monitoring tools to adjust NEG configurations for optimal performance and to address any potential bottlenecks. More information can be found in the Cloud Monitoring documentation.

Implementing zonal NEGs helps maintain a resilient and performant architecture by providing geographically distributed endpoints for handling application loads. For additional security and best practices, refer to the overall HTTP(S) Load Balancing best practices document.

countermeasure.name: Control access and ensure Least Privilege to Cloud Load Balancing
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to Cloud Load Balancing services, implement IAM access control and apply the principle of least privilege. Begin by identifying the specific roles and permissions required for users interacting with Cloud Load Balancing. Assign these roles using the IAM & Admin section in the Google Cloud Console, ensuring that users and service accounts have only the permissions essential for their functions.

Consult the official Google Cloud IAM documentation to understand predefined roles that could be used to restrict access effectively. Use custom IAM roles if predefined roles do not meet your organization's specific needs.
Be cautious when granting the roles like roles/owner or roles/editor, as they provide broad access to resources.

Regularly review IAM policies by setting up audits and monitoring using IAM audit logs to identify potential over-privileged access. Periodically adjust permissions to align with current job responsibilities and security policies, removing unnecessary rights from users who no longer require them.

Incorporate the best practice guidelines from the Load Balancing Best Practices document to ensure robust security postures for load balancing activities. Regularly update your knowledge and practices according to the most current recommendations provided by Google Cloud.

countermeasure.name: Enable connection draining on Load Balancers
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the graceful completion of ongoing requests during maintenance or shutdown of backend instances in GCP Load Balancing, you should configure connection draining. Connection draining allows existing connections to finish processing before the instance is terminated, thus preventing disruption in service and improving reliability.

Here is a step-by-step guidance on implementing connection draining:

  1. Access Google Cloud Console: Sign in to your Google Cloud Console.

  2. Navigate to Load Balancing: In the console, select Network services and then Load balancing.

  3. Choose the Load Balancer: Locate the load balancer you wish to modify by selecting it from the available list.

  4. Edit Backend Service: Under the selected load balancer, navigate to the Backend configuration tab and click on the backend service that you want to set up connection draining for.

  5. Configure Connection Draining: In the backend service settings, set the desired connection draining timeout value, which defines how long the load balancer will wait for current connections to end before forcefully closing them. Ensure this timeout period aligns with your application's expected request duration for optimal results.

  6. Save and Apply Changes: After setting the connection draining timeout, save your changes and allow the load balancer to refresh its configuration.

For further details and the most updated procedures on configuring connection draining within GCP Load Balancing, please refer to the official documentation available at GCP Connection Draining.

countermeasure.name: Enable logging of load balancing health checks
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive visibility into the performance and status of your Cloud Load Balancers, it is essential to enable logging for health checks. This measure will allow you to monitor the operational health of backend services and promptly detect any issues.

To implement logging for health checks in Google Cloud Load Balancing, follow these steps:

  1. Enable Google Cloud Logging: Begin by ensuring that Google Cloud Logging is enabled for your Google Cloud project. This service will aggregate log data, including health check logs, for analysis and monitoring. More details can be found in the Google Cloud Logging documentation.
  2. Configure Logging in Load Balancer: Navigate to your load balancer settings in the Google Cloud Console. For HTTP(S) Load Balancers, set up or edit your existing load balancer and proceed to enable logging under the backend services or backend buckets. Refer to the step-by-step guide on configuring a load balancer for assistance.
  3. Verify and Specify Logging Parameters: Once logging is activated, verify that the appropriate log types are being captured. Typically, you should log both successful and failed health checks to obtain a comprehensive view of your load balancer's performance.
  4. Monitor and Review Logs: Utilize Google Cloud's operations suite to actively monitor and review health check logs. This will help you identify trends, troubleshoot issues, and ensure optimal performance.

By carefully enabling and configuring logging for health checks, you can improve security, optimize performance, and ensure the reliability of your Cloud Load Balancers.

countermeasure.name: Securely store your credentials and rotate Google Service account keys
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your GCP Load Balancing setup, it's imperative to manage and protect sensitive credentials such as service account keys effectively. Using Google Cloud's Secret Manager simplifies the storage and management of these secrets securely. Here are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Store Service Account Keys Securely:
    • Navigate to the Google Cloud Console and access the Secret Manager service.
    • Create a new secret to store your Google service account key. Upload the JSON key file and configure versioning if needed.
    • Restrict access to the secret by setting appropriate IAM policies, allowing only necessary users and services access.
  2. Configure Automatic Rotation:
    • Set up secret rotation by following the guidelines outlined in Managing Secrets documentation.
    • Enable the automatic rotation feature by specifying a rotation schedule, ensuring that secrets are rotated periodically to minimize exposure risks.
  3. Update Load Balancing Configuration:
    • Ensure that your load balancing configuration references service account keys securely stored in Secret Manager.
    • Reload or refresh configurations to apply new key versions after rotation, thus maintaining uninterrupted secure operations.

Implementing these measures enhances the security posture of your Google Cloud Platform services by reducing the attack surface associated with exposed credentials. For further details, refer to the HTTP(S) Load Balancing best practices.

countermeasure.name: Use Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and control access to your applications behind Google Cloud Load Balancers, implement Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP). IAP provides secure, perimeter-less access control to your web applications hosted on Google Cloud, ensuring that only authenticated and authorized users can access your services.

Step-by-Step Guidance for Cloud Engineers:

  1. Enable IAP API: Begin by enabling the Identity-Aware Proxy API in your Google Cloud Platform project. This can be done via the GCP Console or using the command line.
    • Console: Navigate to APIs & Services > Library and enable the IAP API.
    • Command Line: Use the following command: 
      gcloud services enable iap.googleapis.com
  2. Configure OAuth consent screen: Set up your OAuth consent screen to declare what resources your application will access and who can use it. This is required to use IAP as it relies on OAuth 2.0.
    • Navigate to API & Services > Credentials > OAuth consent screen. Configure the necessary information like application name, support email, and authorized domains.
  3. Define IAP-secured Resources: Identify the load balancers and the associated backend services you wish to secure with IAP. Ensure all requests to these resources are routed through the IAP.
  4. Configure Backend Services for IAP: Ensure your backend service is compatible with IAP. This requires using HTTPS for communication with the backend.
  5. Set up Access Controls: Define access policies to manage which user and group accounts can access your applications via IAP. Use IAM roles to grant permissions appropriately. Test Configuration: After setting up IAP, thoroughly test it to ensure that the authentication and authorization mechanisms are functioning as expected. Attempt to access the application both with and without the required permissions to verify that access controls are correctly enforced.

By implementing Identity-Aware Proxy with your GCP Load Balancers, you add an extra layer of security by enforcing application-level security policies without relying on a traditional perimeter-based network security model.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Unrestricted network access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Allowing inbound traffic from all sources can significantly expose your system to a variety of attacks, leading to potential security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors who take advantage of unrestricted access to attempt unauthorized entry or launch DDoS attacks.
Impacts
Potential impacts include service disruption, unauthorized access to sensitive data, resource exhaustion, and increased vulnerability to DDoS attacks.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by flooding the network with illegitimate traffic, causing a denial of service for legitimate users. Alternatively, a hacker might gain unauthorized access to internal systems by exploiting open ports.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unmonitored load balancing health status
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of visibility into the health of Load Balancers can lead to undetected failures or vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include unauthorized users or attackers who exploit the lack of monitoring and visibility in order to introduce vulnerabilities, causing failures or performance issues that go unnoticed.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat can include failure to detect and resolve issues promptly, potentially leading to degraded performance, increased downtime, and susceptibility to attacks or exploits that could have been prevented with proper monitoring.
Example Attack Scenarios
An example involves an attacker exploiting a vulnerability that goes unnoticed due to insufficient health monitoring, allowing them to cause a denial of service attack by overloading the server resources, leaving legitimate users unable to access services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

threat.name: Service fisruption furing Load Balancer maintenance
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of proper draining configurations during load balancer maintenance can result in abrupt terminations of active connections. This can affect service availability and lead to interrupted user sessions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include system administrators who fail to configure connection draining settings, as well as automated systems or scripts executing maintenance tasks without adequately managing active connections.
Impacts
The impact includes potential disruption of online services, loss of user data in transit, and negative user experience. This can further result in loss of revenue and damage to service reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An administrator schedules routine maintenance on the load balancer without enabling connection draining. As a result, active sessions are dropped abruptly, leading to loss of user activity data and complaints from users of interrupted services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Inefficient load distribution across zones
threat.desc:
General threat description
Poor configuration of Load Balancers can result in unequal resource allocation across various zones, which may negatively impact performance and availability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or system administrators who lack knowledge or make errors in the configuration of load balancers.
Impacts
This can lead to significant performance degradation and potential downtime, affecting user experience and business operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
A security administrator erroneously configures a load balancer to route all traffic to a single zone, overwhelming it and causing service delays or outages.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Cloud Load Balancing
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control may allow unauthorized users to configure or misuse Cloud Load Balancing, leading to potential disruptions or attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users exploiting misconfigured access controls to gain access to Cloud Load Balancing settings.
Impacts
Potential disruptions, data breaches, or service unavailability due to unauthorized configuration changes or misuse.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a poorly configured load balancer and reroutes traffic, causing an outage or redirects users to a malicious site.

threat.name: Compromised credentials and key management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failure to properly secure credentials and rotate keys increases the risk of unauthorized access, potentially leading to security breaches in cloud infrastructure.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or insiders who gain access to unsecured or outdated credentials can exploit this vulnerability to infiltrate cloud resources.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and disruption of services, ultimately damaging the organization's reputation and causing financial loss.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers static credentials hardcoded in an application and uses them to access sensitive cloud resources. Additionally, a former employee uses unexpired credentials to access critical systems, leading to data exfiltration.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to applications behind load balancers
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access control can lead to unauthorized access to backend applications through load balancing, potentially exposing sensitive data and compromising application integrity.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious users or insiders may exploit misconfigurations in access control settings of the load balancer to gain unauthorized access to backend systems.
Impacts
Unauthorized access may result in data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and diminished trust in system security.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers and exploits a misconfigured load balancer rule that lacks proper access control restrictions, allowing them to directly interact with critical backend systems without authentication.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-1007
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1007: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

weakness.name: CWE-1037
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1037: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Apply Bucket Lock policies to enforce retention periods for stored objects
countermeasure.desc:
Apply Bucket Lock policies in GCP Storage to enforce mandatory retention periods on objects within storage buckets. This prevents any deletion or modification of data during the specified retention period. This security control is essential for protecting critical data from accidental deletions, overwrites, or unauthorized changes. Once configured, the retention period cannot be shortened or removed, offering robust protection for sensitive data that must comply with regulatory or legal retention requirements. Bucket Lock can also be combined with object holds to protect individual objects beyond the retention settings.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Bucket Lock Documentation

reference.name: 2.3 - Ensure That Retention Policies on Cloud Storage Buckets Used for Exporting Logs Are Configured Using Bucket Lock

countermeasure.name: Configure signed URLs to provide time-limited access to storage objects
countermeasure.desc:
Configure signed URLs in GCP Storage to allow time-limited access to specific objects without exposing the entire bucket. Signed URLs provide a secure mechanism to grant temporary access to an object for a defined period, after which the URL expires and access is revoked. This is particularly useful for scenarios where you need to share objects with external users or systems in a controlled manner. By using signed URLs, you ensure that access to sensitive objects is restricted, protecting the storage bucket while still enabling authorized users to retrieve the needed files within a specified time frame.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Signed URLs Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enable object versioning in GCP Storage buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Enable object versioning in GCP Storage to automatically retain prior versions of objects stored in buckets. This feature ensures that whenever an object is modified, deleted, or overwritten, the previous versions remain accessible for recovery. Object versioning is an essential safeguard against accidental deletions or modifications, allowing you to restore earlier versions of files when necessary. This feature is particularly useful in environments where multiple users or automated processes interact with the same objects, reducing the risk of permanent data loss due to human error or unexpected overwrites.

When object versioning is enabled, GCP Storage keeps track of object changes by assigning unique version identifiers to each version of an object. You can access, restore, or even delete specific object versions as needed. This can be configured at the bucket level, and its important to consider implementing version lifecycle management to control the storage cost of maintaining old versions by automatically deleting older versions based on your organizations data retention policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Object Versioning Documentation

countermeasure.name: Use fine-grained access control for object-level permissions in GCP Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Leverage fine-grained access control to enforce more precise, object-level permissions within GCP Storage. Unlike bucket-level permissions, fine-grained control allows you to assign specific roles and access permissions directly to individual storage objects. This ensures that users and services only have the minimum required access to specific data, greatly reducing the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, or unintentional modifications. This is particularly useful for environments where different users or services need varying levels of access to objects within the same bucket. For instance, one user might need read access to a subset of objects, while another might require write permissions to other objects. By applying object-level roles, you can tailor security settings to align with your organizations data protection policies, improving overall security and compliance.

Additionally, fine-grained access control integrates with Google Cloud IAM, allowing you to define roles and assign them based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring that users and services can only interact with data that they are authorized to access. It is also advisable to regularly review and audit permissions to ensure that access remains appropriate over time and does not violate security policies.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Fine-Grained Access Control Documentation

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion or overwrite of objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Accidental deletion or overwrite of storage objects occurs when authorized users or automated processes inadvertently delete or overwrite important files. This can result in permanent data loss or corruption, impacting business continuity and potentially violating data retention policies.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Human error, misconfigured scripts, or processes with improper access rights can lead to accidental deletion or overwriting of data. Lack of backup or versioning policies exacerbates the risk.

Impacts

  • Loss of critical data leading to business disruptions.
  • Potential violation of data retention and compliance regulations.
  • Increased recovery costs due to the need for manual data restoration.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A developer accidentally deletes production data while performing routine maintenance due to incorrect permissions.
  2. A misconfigured automated backup script overwrites important storage objects with outdated or corrupted data.
  3. An employee accidentally overwrites a vital document in the storage bucket, resulting in the loss of an unversioned file without recovery options.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inappropriate access to storage objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inappropriate access to storage objects occurs when unauthorized users or services gain access to objects in GCP Storage. This could lead to unintended exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized modification, or deletion of critical data. Such access can result from misconfigurations in access control policies, excessive permissions, or lack of proper identity and access management controls.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigured Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies, public exposure of buckets, or weak access control mechanisms. Insider threats, compromised service accounts, or overly permissive roles can also lead to inappropriate access.

Impacts

  • Data breaches and exposure of sensitive information.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of data.
  • Loss of trust, compliance violations, and potential financial loss.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A storage bucket is mistakenly configured with public access, allowing unauthorized users to access confidential company files.
  2. An internal employee with excessive permissions unintentionally deletes or modifies objects within a storage bucket.
  3. A compromised service account with access to storage objects is used by an attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1619 - Cloud Storage Object Discovery

threat.name: Uncontrolled public access to objects
threat.desc:
General threat description
Uncontrolled public access to storage objects occurs when storage buckets or objects are inadvertently configured to be publicly accessible. This can lead to unauthorized individuals being able to view, modify, or delete the objects, potentially exposing sensitive data or compromising business operations.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Misconfigured storage bucket permissions, over-permissive access settings, or lack of regular audits can result in public access. Attackers or external users can exploit such misconfigurations to access confidential or sensitive data.

Impacts

  • Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized parties.
  • Unauthorized modification or deletion of critical information.
  • Damage to reputation and compliance violations.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A companys storage bucket is misconfigured to allow public access, resulting in confidential client data being accessible to anyone with the link.
  2. A developer mistakenly applies overly permissive access control policies to storage objects, leading to sensitive project data being accessed and leaked.
  3. An attacker scans for publicly exposed GCP Storage buckets and downloads proprietary files from an unsecured bucket.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unauthorized data modification
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized data modification occurs when storage objects are altered without proper authorization, leading to potential data corruption, integrity issues, or security breaches. This can result from misconfigured access controls, compromised accounts, or malicious insider activity.

Threat agents/attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers exploiting weak access control policies. Misconfigured permissions can provide unauthorized users with the ability to modify data.

Impacts

  • Data corruption or integrity loss.
  • Breach of confidentiality and trust.
  • Potential legal and compliance violations due to unauthorized data changes.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to a poorly secured user account and modifies sensitive financial data stored in the cloud.
  2. A malicious insider alters critical operational data to disrupt business operations without proper authorization.
  3. An external attacker exploits misconfigured permissions to inject malicious data into a storage object, causing application failures.

weakness.name: CWE-1109
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1109: Use of Same Variable for Multiple Purposes The code contains a callable, block, or other code element in which the same variable is used to control more than one unique task or store more than one instance of data.

weakness.name: CWE-115
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-115: Misinterpretation of Input The product misinterprets an input, whether from an attacker or another product, in a security-relevant fashion.

weakness.name: CWE-263
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-263: Password Aging with Long Expiration The product supports password aging, but the expiration period is too long.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Implement regular firmware updates and vulnerability monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Configure the Receipt Laptop to automatically check for firmware updates on a regular schedule and promptly install the latest security patches. Establish a process to continuously monitor vendor advisories and vulnerability bulletins to identify and address emerging threats as soon as they are reported. Integrate these update procedures into your standard maintenance routines and, where feasible, automate the update process to minimize manual intervention and reduce the risk of human error. This proactive approach ensures that the laptop remains secure against known vulnerabilities, thereby protecting sensitive data and maintaining system integrity.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53

countermeasure.name: Implement robust encryption for data transmissions
countermeasure.desc:
Configure the laptop to deploy strong encryption protocols, such as TLS or IPSec, for all communications with connected systems. This ensures that sensitive data is protected from unauthorized interception and tampering during transit. Integrate encryption into the network stack and enforce secure key management practices to maintain data confidentiality and integrity. Regularly audit and update the encryption settings to comply with evolving industry standards and emerging threats, thereby ensuring continuous secure operation.

References:

  • NIST Cryptographic Standards

countermeasure.name: Implement tamper-resistant enclosures with intrusion detection
countermeasure.desc:
Secure the laptop by installing it in a tamper-resistant enclosure that includes physical locks and integrated intrusion detection sensors. This control is designed to prevent unauthorized physical access by deterring tampering attempts and promptly alerting administrators to any suspicious activity. Regularly inspect and maintain these physical security measures to ensure they remain effective against evolving threats.

References:

countermeasure.name: Procure components from trusted vendors and verify authenticity
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all hardware components used in the laptop are sourced exclusively from trusted vendors. This control involves verifying the authenticity of each component through recognized certifications and conducting regular supply chain audits. By implementing these measures, you minimize the risk of counterfeit or tampered parts being integrated into the system, thereby enhancing the overall security and reliability of the hardware. Establish clear procurement guidelines and maintain detailed records of vendor certifications to ensure continuous compliance with security standards.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-161

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unencrypted data transmission occurs when sensitive information exchanged between the laptop and connected systems is sent in plaintext without any encryption. This lack of protection makes the data vulnerable to interception and unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Cybercriminals: Using packet sniffers, man-in-the-middle attacks, or other eavesdropping tools to capture unencrypted data.
  • Insider Threats: Authorized personnel exploiting unsecured communication channels to access or manipulate data.
  • Exploitation of Weak Network Protocols: Attackers targeting unprotected or misconfigured network protocols to intercept transmitted data.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive information, such as credentials or confidential documents, can be exposed to unauthorized parties.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Intercepted data might be altered, leading to misinformation or corrupted records.
  • Regulatory and Compliance Risks: Failure to encrypt data transmissions may violate data protection regulations, resulting in legal or financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker on a public Wi-Fi network uses a packet sniffer to intercept unencrypted data transmitted from the laptop, capturing sensitive information like login credentials.
  • During a man-in-the-middle attack, an adversary intercepts and alters data exchanged between the laptop and a corporate server, resulting in compromised communications and potential data manipulation.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-408 - Unencrypted Sensitive Data Communication

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Supply chain attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Supply chain attacks occur when attackers compromise the laptop's components during manufacturing, distribution, or procurement. This can result in counterfeit or malicious parts being introduced, which may include hidden backdoors or reduced quality, ultimately undermining the device's overall security and functionality.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Suppliers: Vendors or intermediaries who deliberately introduce compromised or counterfeit components.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with access to the supply chain who may alter or substitute components for malicious purposes.
  • Interception and Tampering: Attackers intercept shipments and replace genuine parts with malicious ones during transit.

Impacts

  • Compromised Security: Malicious components can provide attackers with unauthorized access or control over the laptop.
  • System Instability: Counterfeit or substandard parts may lead to hardware malfunctions or system failures.
  • Data Breach Risks: Embedded backdoors or vulnerabilities can lead to data exfiltration and compromise sensitive information.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker collaborates with a rogue supplier to embed counterfeit microchips in laptops during manufacturing, which later allow remote control or data theft once deployed.
  • During transit, an adversary intercepts and replaces critical components with tampered parts, resulting in widespread vulnerabilities across an organization's laptop fleet.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-116 - Latent Privileged Access Port

threat.name: Unauthorized physical tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized physical tampering involves an attacker gaining direct physical access to the laptop to alter, damage, or replace its hardware components or modify firmware. Such tampering bypasses software security controls and can lead to the insertion of malicious devices, alteration of critical settings, or damage to the system, ultimately compromising the laptop's integrity and functionality.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Intruders: External individuals who break into secured areas or exploit weak physical security measures to access the laptop.
  • Insider Threats: Authorized personnel who abuse their access privileges to modify or sabotage the laptop intentionally.
  • Opportunistic Attackers: Individuals who exploit temporary lapses in physical security, such as unattended devices in public spaces or unsecured environments.

Impacts

  • Hardware Compromise: Tampering can lead to the installation of unauthorized hardware components (e.g., keyloggers or malicious chips) that facilitate further exploitation.
  • Firmware Manipulation: Attackers may modify the firmware, implanting persistent malware or backdoors that evade detection and allow unauthorized control.
  • Operational Disruption: Altered or damaged hardware can cause system instability, data loss, or complete device failure, disrupting business operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker gains access to a laptop in a poorly secured office, physically installs a hardware keylogger, and later retrieves it to harvest sensitive login credentials.
  • A disgruntled employee uses their authorized access to tamper with the laptop's firmware during routine maintenance, installing a covert backdoor that enables remote control of the device.
  • In a public setting, an opportunistic attacker temporarily steals a laptop, modifies critical hardware components, and returns the device, leaving it compromised without immediate detection.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-406 - Unauthorized Messages or Connections

threat.name: Outdated firmware vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Outdated firmware vulnerabilities occur when the laptops BIOS/UEFI or embedded firmware is not updated with the latest security patches. This leaves the system exposed to known exploits that can be leveraged by attackers to bypass security controls, modify boot processes, or implant malicious code.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Cybercriminals using automated tools to scan for laptops with outdated firmware and exploit known vulnerabilities.
  • Insider Threats: Personnel who neglect firmware updates or deliberately maintain outdated systems, inadvertently creating exploitable vulnerabilities.
  • Automated Exploits: Bots and malware that continuously search for and target devices with unpatched firmware.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Control: Attackers may gain low-level access to the laptop, potentially installing persistent malware that evades detection by traditional security measures.
  • System Instability: Exploitation of firmware vulnerabilities can cause system crashes, unexpected behavior, or complete system failure.
  • Data Integrity and Confidentiality Risks: A compromised firmware layer can lead to unauthorized data access, manipulation, or theft, undermining trust in the system.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An external attacker employs an automated scanning tool to locate laptops running outdated firmware and exploits a known vulnerability to gain remote access, installing a rootkit that remains hidden from the operating system.
  • An insider delays applying firmware updates, leaving the laptop vulnerable; subsequently, a malware campaign targets these unpatched systems to disrupt critical operations and steal sensitive information.

countermeasure.name: Deploy tamper-resistant enclosures and detection sensors for tablet protection
countermeasure.desc:
Implement a robust physical security strategy for the tablet by utilizing tamper-resistant enclosures to shield internal components, applying tamper-evident seals to visibly indicate any unauthorized access, and integrating built-in sensors that monitor for physical disturbances. This multi-layered approach helps to detect and deter physical tampering attempts, ensuring the devices integrity and protecting sensitive data.
References: 

  • NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5

Configure the tablet to restrict application installations to a predefined whitelist and enforce the use of official app stores only. Additionally, implement a mechanism to verify digital signatures on all applications before installation, ensuring that only trusted and verified software can run on the device. This approach minimizes the risk of installing malicious or unapproved applications, thereby safeguarding the tablets integrity and user data.

countermeasure.name: Implement multi-factor authentication and strong access controls for tablet access
countermeasure.desc:
Configure the tablet's authentication system to enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) along with strong password policies that require complexity, regular rotation, and account lockout on repeated failures. In addition, implement secure session management controls such as automatic session timeouts and token validation to prevent session hijacking. These measures ensure that only authorized users can access the tablet, significantly reducing the risk of unauthorized access and related security breaches.

countermeasure.name: Use strong TLS/SSL encryption for tablet communications
countermeasure.desc:
Configure the tablet and its associated network infrastructure to enforce the use of TLS/SSL encryption for all data exchanges. This involves setting up the device to communicate exclusively over TLS 1.2 or later, ensuring that all server certificates are properly validated and that outdated protocols and cipher suites are disabled. This control helps maintain data confidentiality, even if intercepted, and reduces the risk of man-in-the-middle attacks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers can intercept unencrypted data transmissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers can intercept unencrypted data transmissions between the tablet and connected systems. Without encryption, sensitive information such as personal data, credentials, and application commands is exposed, making it vulnerable to interception and manipulation.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, or state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors:
    • Passive eavesdropping on unsecured or public Wi-Fi networks.
    • Man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks during data exchange between the tablet and remote servers.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential information.
  • Data Integrity Loss: Potential modification of data, leading to inaccurate information or compromised operations.
  • Privacy Violations: Exposure of personal user data, leading to privacy concerns and regulatory issues.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Public Wi-Fi Eavesdropping: An attacker on an unsecured public Wi-Fi network intercepts data transmitted from the tablet to a cloud service, capturing login credentials and personal information.
  • MITM Attack: An adversary positions themselves between the tablet and its destination server, intercepting and altering communications to inject malicious commands or harvest sensitive data.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-408 - Unencrypted Sensitive Data Communication

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers may exploit weak authentication controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers may exploit weak authentication controls on the tablet, potentially gaining unauthorized access and bypassing security measures, which could lead to data breaches and unauthorized system modifications.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insider threats, and opportunistic hackers.
  • Vectors:
    • Brute-force attacks to guess weak or default credentials.
    • Credential stuffing using leaked passwords.
    • Exploitation of poorly implemented session management.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can gain control over the tablet and access sensitive data.
  • Data Breach: Exposure of personal information and confidential data.
  • Operational Disruption: Manipulation or disruption of device functionality, impacting user experience.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Brute-Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to repeatedly attempt logins with common or default passwords until access is granted.
  • Credential Stuffing: Attackers leverage compromised passwords from other breaches to access the tablet if weak authentication controls are in place.
  • Session Hijacking: Exploiting weak session management, an attacker hijacks an active session to impersonate a legitimate user.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-316 - Incorrect Certificate Verification Allows Authentication Bypass

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers may install untrusted applications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers may install untrusted applications on the tablet, which can introduce malware or unauthorized functionalities that compromise the devices security and the user's data.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, rogue developers, and malicious insiders.
  • Vectors:
    • Distribution of malicious apps through unofficial app stores or phishing links.
    • Social engineering tactics to trick users into downloading and installing compromised software.

Impacts

  • Malware Infection: Installation of applications that can steal data, monitor user activities, or provide remote access to attackers.
  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive personal or corporate information stored on the tablet.
  • System Compromise: Degradation of system performance and potential unauthorized control over device functionalities.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Phishing and Social Engineering: An attacker sends a deceptive link via email or messaging apps that leads the user to an unofficial app store hosting a malicious application disguised as a legitimate tool.
  • Rogue App Installation: A user inadvertently installs an application from an untrusted source that installs background services to monitor and transmit personal data to a remote server.

threat.name: Attackers may physically tamper with the device
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers may physically tamper with the tablet by gaining unauthorized access to its hardware, allowing them to modify internal components, extract sensitive data, or install malicious modifications that undermine the devices integrity.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Opportunistic thieves, insiders, or vandal attackers.
  • Vectors:
    • Direct physical access due to inadequate physical security measures.
    • Exploiting exposed or accessible ports and interfaces on the tablet.

Impacts

  • Data Extraction: Physical access can lead to the extraction of sensitive data stored on the device.
  • System Compromise: Tampering can introduce malicious hardware or software modifications that disrupt normal operations.
  • Loss of Device Integrity: Unauthorized modifications can compromise the reliability and trustworthiness of the device.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Direct Device Tampering: An attacker gains physical access to a tablet left unattended in a public space, removes or alters critical hardware components, and installs tools to bypass security controls.
  • Insider Manipulation: A disgruntled employee with physical access to the tablet tamper with its hardware to facilitate data theft or unauthorized system modifications.

customField.value: EMB3D - TID-114 - Peripheral Data Bus Interception
